questions.question: The WHO has formulated a Global Action Plan for the prevention and control ofnon-communicable diseases. Which of the following is not a voluntary global target underthis initiative?

options.A: 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol
options.B: 30% relative reduction in mean population intake of sodium
options.C: 10% relative reduction in prevalence of insufficient physical activity
options.D: 10% relative reduction in use of trans-fat for cooking

questions.explanation: A 10 percent relative reduction in the use of trans-fat for cooking is not a voluntary global targetunder the WHO Global Action Plan for prevention and control of non-communicable diseases.There are 9 targets under this plan which are to be achieved by 2025. questions.question: Project MONICA is related to:
questions.explanation: Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.It stands for multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. Itwas done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in differentcountries.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the relationship between smoking andcoronary heart disease (CHD)?

options.A: Smoking can cause sudden death from CHD.
options.B: Filters in cigarettes are protective against the development of CHD.
options.C: Risk of developing CHD 10-20 years after the cessation of smoking is equal in smokers and nonsmokers.
options.D: Degree of risk of developing CHD is directly related to the number of cigarettes smoked perday.

questions.explanation: Filters are probably not protective against the development of coronary heart disease in smokers.Smoking is a modifiable risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD). The degree of risk is directlyrelated to the number of cigarettes smoked per day. Several mechanisms have been suggested forthis:• Carbon monoxide induced atherogenesis• Nicotine stimulation of adrenergic drive• Lipid metabolism with fall in levels of HDLCigarettes also increase the risk of sudden death in patients with CHD who are below 50 years ofage. The risk of death from CHD decreases with the cessation of smoking. The risk declines quite328substantially within one year of stopping smoking and more gradually thereafter until, after 10-20 years, it is the same as that of non-smokers.Risk factors for coronary heart disease are:• Modifiable:••Cigarette smokingHigh blood pressure• Elevated serum cholesterol• Diabetes• Obesity•••Sedentary habitsStress• Non-modifiable:•Age• Sex•Family history• Genetic factors• Personality

questions.question: 321A chronic smoker was found to have a deranged lipid profile during his annual healthcheckup. Which of the following variables tested is most directly associated with the risk ofdeveloping coronary heart disease?
questions.explanation: The plasma LDL level is most directly associated with the risk of developing coronary heartdisease (CHD).HDL is protective against the development of CHD. Its levels should ideally be more than 40mg/dl.Recent evidence shows that levels of Apolipoprotein-A-1 and Apolipoprotein-B are betterpredictors of CHD than HDL or LDL.VLDL is more strongly associated with the risk of developing peripheral vascular disease.

questions.question: A 45-year-old diabetic male is concerned about his risk of developing coronary heart disease.What cholesterol/HDL ratio would you aim to achieve in this patient?
questions.explanation: A cholesterol/HDL ratio <3.5 is recommended for the prevention of coronary heart disease(CHD).

questions.question: While conducting a screening camp for coronary heart disease, you encounter the followingpeople. Who among them is at the highest risk for developing this disease?

options.A: A person who is competitive and ambitious
options.B: A person who is calm and relaxed
options.C: A person who tends to suppress their emotions
options.D: An introverted person with negative affectivity

questions.explanation: 329A person who is competitive and ambitious is said to have a type A personality. Such people aremore prone to develop coronary heart disease (CHD). Personality type is a non-modifiable riskfactor for CHD.Risk factors for coronary heart disease are:• Modifiable:•Cigarette smoking• High blood pressure• Elevated serum cholesterol• Diabetes•Obesity• Sedentary habits• Stress• Non-modifiable:Age• Sex• Family history• Genetic factors•• PersonalityOption B: A calm and relaxed person is said to have a type B personality.Option C: A person who tends to suppress their emotions, especially negative emotions, is said tohave a type C personality.Option D: A person with negative affectivity and social inhibition is said to have a type Dpersonality.

questions.question: A 45-year-old obese woman enquires about ways she can reduce her risk of coronary arterydisease. Which of the following dietary modifications would you suggest?

options.A: Reduction of salt intake to less than 10g per day
options.B: Consumption of saturated fats limited to less than 10% of the total energy intake
options.C: Reduction of total fat intake to less than 5% of total energy intake
options.D: Dietary cholesterol increased to above 100 mg/1000 kcal energy intake322

questions.explanation: Limiting the consumption of saturated fats to less than 10% of total energy intake isrecommended for the prevention of coronary artery disease.The WHO'S Expert Committee suggested certain dietary modifications for the prevention ofcoronary artery disease. These include:• Reduction of the total fat intake to 20-30% of total energy intake•Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake•• A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day• Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains andlegumes)• Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less330

questions.question: A 50-year-old man, under treatment for hypertension for the past two months, is found tohave a blood pressure of 144/96 mmHg. How will you grade it according to the Europeansociety of cardiology guidelines-2018?
questions.explanation: According to the European society of cardiology guidelines-2018, a patient having a systolicBP≥140 and a diastolic BP≥90 mmHg is classified as having grade 1 hypertension.

questions.question: A doctor records the BP of a patient as 142/90mmHg. One hour later, another doctor recordsthe BP of the same patient as 160/98 mmHg. Both the readings are measured with the sameapparatus under the same emotional and physical state of the patient. What type of error isseen here?
questions.explanation: Such errors can arise due to differences in hearing acuity and interpretation of Korotkoff sounds.The types of errors that can occur during the measurement of blood pressure include:••Observer errors - due to difference in hearing acuity and interpretation of Korotkoff soundsInstrumental errors - due to a leaking valve or cuffs that do not encircle the arm completely• Subject errors due to anxiety, fear, etc. of the patient-331

questions.explanation: The above diagram depicts the "rule of halves", which shows the distribution of hypertension inthe community. The number 2 in this diagram denotes normotensive subjects.The rule of halves is a way of depicting the iceberg phenomenon seen in hypertension. questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?

options.A: BP increases with age in all individuals
options.B: BP falls steadily in the elderly
options.C: Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
options.D: BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.explanation: If the blood pressure of individuals is followed up over years from early childhood to adult life,low blood pressures tend to remain low and high blood pressures become higher as theindividuals grow older. This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure isdescribed as tracking.This is helpful in identifying children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertensionin the future.Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities havebeen identified whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intakeand calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.question: Which of the following is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever in a low riskpopulation?
questions.explanation: Polyarthralgia is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever in a low risk population.

questions.question: A child having strep throat is being prescribed benzathine penicillin G. Which level ofprevention of rheumatic fever does this intervention fall under?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is an example of primary mode of prevention of rheumatic fever. This isbecause the patient only has strep throat and rheumatic fever has not developed yet.In case benzathine penicillin G is given to a patient with rheumatic fever to prevent furthercomplications, then it becomes secondary level of prevention.

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy with rheumatic fever developed carditis which subsequently healed in acouple of weeks. How long will you administer benzathine penicillin G for secondaryprophylaxis to him?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, benzathine penicillin G for secondary prophylaxis should be given for 10years from the last attack i.e, till 26 years of age. The given case is of rheumatic fever with carditisbut with no residual valvular disease, for which secondary prophylaxis is given for 10 years fromthe last attack or till 21 years of age, whichever is longer.Recommendations for the duration of secondary prophylaxis with penicillin:Category of the patientRheumatic fever without carditisRheumatic fever with carditisbut with no residual valvulardiseaseRheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease evident clinically or on echoDuration of prophylaxisFor 5 years after the last attack or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)For 10 years after the last attack or until 21 yrs of age (whichever is longer)For 10 years after the last attack or until 40 years of age, or sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

questions.question: Which of the following is not a protective factor for diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation: A higher intake of saturated fats is associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus.Dietary factors that are protective for diabetes mellitus are:•Higher intake of unsaturated fatty acids.• A minimum daily intake of 20g of dietary fibre334• Exclusive breastfeeding

questions.question: Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding the benefits of variousinterventions in diabetes?
questions.explanation: The use of ACE inhibitors in diabetics reduces the risk of nephropathy by 42% and cardiovascularrisk by 22%. Annual eye examination in diabetics reduces the incidence of serious visual loss by60-70%.Interventions in diabetes:•Glycaemic control in diabetics with HbA1C > 9% reduces microvascular disease risk by 30%per 1% drop in HbA1c.• Blood pressure control in patients with BP > 130/80 mmHg reduces microvascular and•macrovascular disease risk by 35% per 10 mmHg drop in blood pressure.Lifestyle modification reduces the incidence of diabetes by 35-58%.• Metformin administered as a preventive therapy reduces the incidence of diabetes by 25-31%.• Proper foot care reduces the risk of serious foot disease by 50-60%.
